00001 #include "Utils All.h"
00002 #include "Language Defines.h"

00004 #ifdef RUSSIAN
00005 
00006 /*
00007 
00008 ******************************************************************************************************
00009 **                                  IMPORTANT TRANSLATION NOTES                                     **
00010 ******************************************************************************************************
00011 
00012 GENERAL TOPWARE INSTRUCTIONS
00013 - Always be aware that German strings should be of equal or shorter length than the English equivalent.  
00014       I know that this is difficult to do on many occasions due to the nature of the German language when 
00015       compared to English.  By doing so, this will greatly reduce the amount of work on both sides.  In 
00016       most cases (but not all), JA2 interfaces were designed with just enough space to fit the English word.  
00017       The general rule is if the string is very short (less than 10 characters), then it's short because of 
00018       interface limitations.  On the other hand, full sentences commonly have little limitations for length.  
00019       Strings in between are a little dicey.
00020 - Never translate a string to appear on multiple lines.  All strings L"This is a really long string...", 
00021       must fit on a single line no matter how long the string is.  All strings start with L" and end with ",
00022 - Never remove any extra spaces in strings.  In addition, all strings containing multiple sentences only 
00023       have one space after a period, which is different than standard typing convention.  Never modify sections 
00024       of strings contain combinations of % characters.  These are special format characters and are always 
00025       used in conjunction with other characters.  For example, %s means string, and is commonly used for names,
00026       locations, items, etc.  %d is used for numbers.  %c%d is a character and a number (such as A9).  
00027       %% is how a single % character is built.  There are countless types, but strings containing these 
00028       special characters are usually commented to explain what they mean.  If it isn't commented, then 
00029       if you can't figure out the context, then feel free to ask SirTech.
00030 - Comments are always started with // Anything following these two characters on the same line are 
00031       considered to be comments.  Do not translate comments.  Comments are always applied to the following 
00032       string(s) on the next line(s), unless the comment is on the same line as a string.  
00033 - All new comments made by SirTech will use "//@@@ comment" (without the quotes) notation.  By searching 
00034       for @@@ everytime you recieve a new version, it will simplify your task and identify special instructions.
00035   Commonly, these types of comments will be used to ask you to abbreviate a string.  Please leave the 
00036       comments intact, and SirTech will remove them once the translation for that particular area is resolved.
00037 - If you have a problem or question with translating certain strings, please use "//!!! comment" 
00038       (without the quotes).  The syntax is important, and should be identical to the comments used with @@@ 
00039       symbols.  SirTech will search for !!! to look for Topware problems and questions.  This is a more 
00040       efficient method than detailing questions in email, so try to do this whenever possible.
00041 
00042 
00043       
00044 FAST HELP TEXT -- Explains how the syntax of fast help text works.
00045 **************
00046 
00047 1) BOLDED LETTERS
00048       The popup help text system supports special characters to specify the hot key(s) for a button.  
00049       Anytime you see a '|' symbol within the help text string, that means the following key is assigned
00050       to activate the action which is usually a button.  
00051 
00052       EX:  L"|Map Screen"
00053 
00054       This means the 'M' is the hotkey.  In the game, when somebody hits the 'M' key, it activates that
00055       button.  When translating the text to another language, it is best to attempt to choose a word that
00056       uses 'M'.  If you can't always find a match, then the best thing to do is append the 'M' at the end
00057       of the string in this format:
00058 
00059       EX:  L"Ecran De Carte (|M)"  (this is the French translation)
00060 
00061       Other examples are used multiple times, like the Esc key  or "|E|s|c" or Space -> (|S|p|a|c|e)
00062 
00063 2) NEWLINE
00064   Any place you see a \n within the string, you are looking at another string that is part of the fast help
00065       text system.  \n notation doesn't need to be precisely placed within that string, but whereever you wish 
00066       to start a new line. 
00067 
00068       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions,\nand allows you to re-enter them manually."
00069 
00070       Would appear as:
00071 
00072                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00073                         and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00074 
00075       NOTE:  It is important that you don't pad the characters adjacent to the \n with spaces.  If we did this
00076              in the above example, we would see
00077 
00078       WRONG WAY -- spaces before and after the \n
00079       EX:  L"Clears all the mercs' positions, \n and allows you to re-enter them manually."
00080 
00081       Would appear as: (the second line is moved in a character)
00082             
00083                         Clears all the mercs' positions,
00084                          and allows you to re-enter them manually.
00085 
00086 
00087 @@@ NOTATION
00088 ************
00089 
00090       Throughout the text files, you'll find an assortment of comments.  Comments are used to describe the
00091       text to make translation easier, but comments don't need to be translated.  A good thing is to search for
00092       "@@@" after receiving new version of the text file, and address the special notes in this manner.  
00093 
00094 !!! NOTATION
00095 ************
00096 
00097       As described above, the "!!!" notation should be used by Topware to ask questions and address problems as
00098       SirTech uses the "@@@" notation.
00099 
00100 */
00101
